Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of Cyclic Loading Induced Microstructure Evolution and Damage in High-Sn Alloys
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Ongoing changes in the electronics industry provide for an urgent need for a quantitative understanding of the behavior of SnAgCu solder alloys in both isothermal and thermal cycling. This kind of materials system is, however, also of considerable scientific interest in its own right. The tetragonal Sn crystal structure provides for extremely anisotropic properties, and the addition of a few percent of Ag leads to cyclic twinning structures with unique properties and behavior. This has particular consequences for overall sample dimensions well below a millimeter. Notably, thermomechanical properties vary strongly with various aspects of the microstructure and its evolution over time. The goal of the proposed research is to establish a quantitative understanding of the evolution of fatigue damage in high-Sn alloys with a few percent Ag and Cu under cyclic loading. Recent work has led to the formulation of a general hypothesis involving direct causal links between dislocation generation and recovery, the build-up of dislocation cell structures, the thermal and strain enhanced grain growth and coarsening of secondary precipitates, the formation and rotation of sub-grains, and the eventual initiation and growth of cracks. It is anticipated that much of this picture will apply to a number of other precipitate hardened metals as well. A systematic study will be conducted to validate and, if necessary, improve upon or revise the above hypothesis. Experimental efforts will focus on the in-depth characterization of dislocation cell structures and eventual sub-grains in selected high-Sn alloys before and after carefully designed combinations of thermomechanical loading. Cycling with varying amplitudes will be particularly effective for the characterization of the underlying mechanisms. Microstructure studies will rely heavily on cross polarized microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, electron backscatter diffraction, focused ion beam sectioning and transmission electron microscopy.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Electronics are serving critical roles in ever more aspects of modern life and of the general functioning of society, and the premature failure of a microelectronics product may have consequences ranging from economical to loss of life. The inexpensive availability of many electronics products may have tremendous consequences in areas ranging from military preparedness and public safety to education, social services and the development of poorer countries around the world. The long term life of a product is most often limited by wear out of the solder joints that connect components to each other or to a printed circuit board. As the industry is forced to transition even high reliability products to environmentally friendly lead free solders there is an urgent need for a level of understanding of damage and failure mechanisms that has yet to be established. This is the focus of the proposed research. Results will help the industry design and manufacture more durable, reliable electronics at lower costs. Graduate and undergraduate students, including a number of minority students, will be trained on state of the art equipment and conduct experiments both at the university and in the laboratory of industrial partner Universal Instruments. At Universal Instruments the students will work closely with Ph.D. level industry engineers. Students will present results at regular meetings of a large industry consortium, as well as at regional conferences and at major scientific conferences. They will also publish their work in peer reviewed journals. Results and experiences will furthermore contribute to the ongoing development of undergraduate and graduate level courses.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Binghamton
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established an understanding of the behavior of a particular group of materials under cyclic loading. The materials are somewhat unique in as far as samples of the dimensions considered (sub-mm) are essentially single crystal. The inelastic deformation was shown to be dominated by a different mechanism than commonly assumed, leading to very different deformation properties than currently used in modeling. The associated evolution of damage varies strongly with the type of loading. Mechanical cycling at fixed temperature, such as in vibration or cyclic bending, leads to crack growth through the grains by a mechanism that involves the evolution of a dislocation structure. This evolution was found to be more complex than commonly expected if the cycling amplitude varied. The temperature variations involved in thermal cycling lead to the evolution of much more extensive dislocation structures and eventually a network of new grain boundaries (a polycrystalline region). Crack growth then proceeds along these boundaries. The properties of the high-Sn alloys in question are dominated by the presence of precipitates which delay the evolution of the new grains (recrystallization) unless the strains induced are very high. Except in very accelerated testing the recrystallization therefore cannot begin until the precipitates have coarsened so that their spacing has increased to a level that depends on the cyclic strain range. 

The behavior in thermal cycling seems to be somewhat unique to these precipitate hardened  materials. The effect of damage on which inelastic deformation mechanism dominates when was found to be shared by metals like Cu, Al, and brass. Indications are also that the evolution of damage in mechanical cycling at fixed temperature is similar. This points to the need for a much broader research effort on a range of metals. 

The mechanistic understanding established has practical consequences for the microelectronics industry where these high-Sn alloys are used everywhere for soldering. The industry makes assessments of the life anticipated in long term service based on accelerated testing together with explicit or implicit extrapolation of the results to service conditions. There is no practical way of validating the interpretation of the results directly, but the observation of apparent inconsistencies between different accelerated test results too often disproves it. The understanding established explains all published 'surprises', lending confidence to its further use. Practical guidelines for testing and interpretations were developed and published. Dissemination of this included sharing it all with relevant industry associations and consortia. Practical outcomes include current discussions of revisions of industry standards.

More generally, an outcome of the results and quantitative understanding is expected to be significant improvements to the assessment of reliability, both in terms of comparisons (which alternative is best?) and in terms of whether reliability is sufficient for a given application. A related outcome may even be the design of materials for which the performance in service has been significantly improved. 

Another kind of outcome has been the exposure of a large number of undergraduate and graduate students to fundamental research and a clear demonstration of how a fundamental understanding can be translated into direct, practical knowledge and tools. 


Last Modified: 03/21/2017
Modified by: Peter Borgesen
